Award.AwardTitle: Metamaterial-Enhanced Electroelastoacoustic Energy Harvesting for Sensor Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to investigate and leverage electroelastoacoustically coupled linear and nonlinear metamaterial-inspired energy harvesting concepts for self-powered sensor systems. The technical approach of this computational and experimental research program combines metamaterial-inspired structures and piezoelectric energy harvesting to extract low-power electricity from structure-borne propagating waves. Wave focusing and funneling, diode mechanisms, frequency bandgaps, and energy localization are some of the unique metamaterial properties that will be explored for improving the efficiency of linear and nonlinear piezoelectric energy harvesting. The research program will achieve its objectives by establishing lumped- and distributed-parameter modeling frameworks coupling the elastoacoustic dynamics of metamaterials and propagating waves with the electroelastic dynamics of piezoelectric energy harvesting, followed by experimental testing of specific configurations to validate performance enhancement.

If successful, the results of this research will yield computational tools and experimental concepts for the potential system-level applications of low-power electricity generation from elastoacoustic waves propagating in the environment of sensor networks. The economic and societal benefits of enabling self-powered sensor nodes include reduction of maintenance costs and chemical waste of conventional batteries in wireless monitoring applications. The multifunctional nature of this class of energy harvesters results in the absorption of wave energy (which would otherwise create undesired noise/vibration) while generating usable electricity. In addition to constituting unprecedented platforms for both resonant and broadband energy harvesting, the frequency range of operation of the considered class of metamaterials can be highly compatible with microelectromechanical system-based energy harvesting. Results from this research will be disseminated through conference presentations, scholarly publications, and academic courses. Educational laboratory activities and classroom modules, developed in partnership with the Georgia Intern Fellowships for Teachers program at Georgia Tech, will expose underrepresented high school students to basic results of the research and to underlying wave mechanics and electroelastoacoustic principles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the last decade, various methods of energy harvesting have been researched toward enabling next-generation self-powered electronic devices for various wireless applications, e.g. low-power sensor nodes used in structural health monitoring. While the harvesting of standing waves and vibrations has been well investigated, the potential of traveling wave energy in structures, i.e. propagating elastic waves, has received much less attention. Importantly, to improve the efficiency of electrical power generation it is required to develop proper strategies for elastic wave energy localization and focusing. To this end, the major goal of this computational and experimental research project was to exploit metamaterial-based/inspired concepts for the enhanced harvesting of structure-borne propagating waves. Both analytical/numerical modeling framework development and experimental validations were among the major tasks. 

The results of this successful research project have been published in journal articles and conference proceedings. The following summarizes the specific project outcomes. 

- We have established electromechanical modeling framework by coupling the wave elastodynamics with the electroelastic behavior of the piezoelectric energy harvester, presented rigorous analyses using these models along with experimental validations for one-dimensional and two-dimensional structural configurations. 

- We have explored and identified methods of efficiency enhancement in one-dimensional problems, beyond wavelength matching, by exploiting various approaches ranging from localized obstacles to electrical resistive-reactive load impedance matching in an effort to maximize the harvested power while minimizing the energy reflected and transmitted from the harvester.

- We have analyzed nonlinear problems of wave energy harvesting with a focus on bistable inclusions and clearence-type nonlinear energy sinks. Bistable inclusions enable broadband elastic wave energy harvesting if the incident wave energy intensity is sufficiently large. Clearance type nonlinearity traps wave energy and thereby results in enhanced harvested energy. 

- We have explored both computational (finite-element) and analytical modeling of elastic wave mirrors for spatial focusing and enhancement of energy harvesting performance. Experiments have been carried out for model validations. Additionally electrode patterning for harvesting energy from side lobes (that occur at certain frequencies) has also been studied both computationally and experimentally.

- We have developed second-generation elastic wave mirrors to avoid bulky material extensions of previous stub-based on continuous mirrors. To this end, structurally-embedded mirror concepts have been enabled through the insertion of metallic beads (e.g. tungsten, lead, steel) into blind holes that form the mirror in the aluminum plate domain. Therefore the resulting mirror substrate keeps its original flat structure while the focusing is achieved successfully as shown through numerical simulations and experiments.

- We have established the first Gradient-Index Phononic Crystal Lens (GRIN-PCL) structure for enhanced plan wave energy harvesting purposes. The proposed GRIN-PCL is formed by an array of blind holes with different diameters on an aluminum plate, without requiring any bulky extensions. Both finite-element simulations and experiments were performed, showing excellent agreement. The harvested power due to GRIN-PCL is enhanced by more than an order of magnitude as compared to the baseline case of using a flat plate.

- We have also explored a method for omnidirectional plane wave energy harvesting through a gradient-based Luneburg lens design. The Luneburg lens uses a radial gradient distribution of the refractive index, hence it can focus plane waves propagating from all directions.

- Finally, we explored 3D printing of a GRIN-PCL on an aluminum plate as the first 3D printed metamaterial-based energy harvester. This bilayer energy harvester (with nylon and aluminum) has a hyperbolic secant-based refractice index profile for the focusing of incident elastic plane wave. 

- As a part of the outreach component, Georgia Tech collaborated with a high school through the GT CEISMC (Center for Education Integrating Science,
Mathematics and Computing) GIFT (Georgia Intern Fellowships for Teachers) program for summer research.  

- The results of this computational and experimental research program may find applications not only in energy harvesting for low-power sensors but also in novel wave devices and electromechanical systems for wave guiding and filtering, among others.
